channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Efforts to Strengthen Afghan Law on Women May Backfire
item.description: Concerns that seeking to amend a law that holds families accountable for women’s mistreatment poses a risk of losing the minimal protections afforded now.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: The scene in a Kabul store selling burqas, a garment that has come to exemplify the many limitations women in Afghanistan face.

item.title: Syria’s Assad Says Peace Talks Likely to Fail
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad backed away from earlier statements by Syrian officials that the government was willing to negotiate with its armed opponents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Buildings damaged this month in Raqqa Province after what rebels said was shelling by Syrian government forces.

item.title: Under Pressure, China Measures Its Impact in Myanmar
item.description: Grass-roots protests against Chinese oil projects are worrying Beijing as it competes for influence in Myanmar with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers in Se Tae, Myanmar, spoke against a project by China’s Wanbao Mining Corporation at the base of Letpadaung mountain.

item.title: South Korea Says North Launches 3 Missiles Into Sea
item.description: The South Korean Defense Ministry said the missiles were fired Saturday off North Korea’s east coast.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Police Officers Are Targets in Wave of Afghan Violence
item.description: Nearly two dozen Afghan police officers and civilians have been killed in the last few days, including a district police official assassinated over a recent anti-Taliban campaign.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Hollande Signs French Gay Marriage Law
item.description: For President François Hollande, passage of the law despite public opposition was a significant victory given his campaign promise to legalize gay marriage within the first year of his administration.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Americas Coalition Puts Marijuana Legalization Up for Discussion
item.description: A report released by the Organization of American States encouraged “flexibility” in how the drug war is carried out, including considering the legalization of marijuana.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: France's Hollande Signs Gay Marriage Law
item.description: French President Francois Hollande has signed into law a bill allowing same-sex marriage, making France the 14th country to legalize gay weddings.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Congress Answers Obama Plan With Smaller Food Aid Changes
item.description: After the Obama administration proposed moving the international food aid program out of the Agriculture Department, the Congressional Agriculture Committees took lesser actions.
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Kennett Love, Times Correspondent in 1950s, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Love was in Iran in 1953 when the C.I.A. plotted against the government, and he also reported on the Suez Canal crisis of 1956.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK

item.title: Fascination With German Leader's More Private Side
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel has kept a tight lid on her personal life during her rise to power, but as she seeks a third four-year term in September, she has cracked open the door.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: The Lede: Long Before Crack Cocaine Allegations, Toronto Mayor Was a Source of Controversy
item.description: Questions have been raised about Mayor Rob Ford’s conduct, temperament and public statements since his early days as a member of the Toronto City Council.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON and LIAM STACK

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Olli Rehn Tries to Shed ‘Austerity’ Label
item.description: Olli Rehn, the European Union’s top economist and a focus of anger across Europe against harsh belt-tightening policies, says he is not a doctrinaire adherent to austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: “If there were a silver bullet, we would have used it already. There is no single silver bullet.”

item.title: Hunting for Syrian Hackers’ Chain of Command
item.description: If researchers prove the Assad regime is closely tied to the Syrian Electronic Army, foreign governments may choose to respond, because the attacks have real-world consequences.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: The Syrian Electronic Army claimed responsibility for hacking The Financial Times on Friday.

item.title: Toronto Mayor Is Accused of Using Cocaine
item.description: A video being shopped by two men with drug connections apparently shows Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto smoking a crack pipe.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto, center, did not speak to reporters outside City Hall on Friday. He has called the charges ridiculous.

item.title: Ex-Iran President Seeks Comeback Against Odds
item.description: Though once widely reviled, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and his reputation as an economic pragmatist and modernizer seem to be resonating with the Iranian public.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A former Iranian president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, center, registered to run for president last Saturday in Tehran.

item.title: Salacious and Sober Collide, Illustrating Hurdles for Italy’s Government
item.description: On the same day, a young Moroccan woman testified in a sex scandal involving former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, and Italy’s new prime minister announced the suspension of a reviled tax.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Karima el-Mahroug after testifying in Milan on Friday in a case involving Mr. Berlusconi. She described a striptease that a former politician, dressed as a nun, performed for Mr. Berlusconi.

item.title: Mountain of Petroleum Coke From Oil Sands Rises in Detroit
item.description: Refining Canada’s petroleum-soaked oil sands produces petroleum coke, and the question of what to do with it has found at least one answer in Detroit, where a large coke pile covers an entire city block.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Fabrizio Costantini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petroleum coke, a waste byproduct of refining oil sands oil, is piling up along the Detroit River.

item.title: U.S.-Russian Diplomacy, With a Personal Touch
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, have found a common purpose in trying to negotiate a Syria settlement, even though positions have not changed.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov on Wednesday in Kiruna, Sweden. The two diplomats have met five times since Mr. Kerry was sworn in in February.

item.title: Gay Rights Rally Is Attacked in Georgia
item.description: A throng of thousands broke through police cordons in Tbilisi to attack a group of about 50 demonstrators, and at least 12 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A crowd swarmed a minibus carrying gay rights activists in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Friday. The police had put the activists on the buses to escape their attackers.

item.title: Rights Group Says It Finds Proof of Torture in Syria
item.description: Human Rights Watch said Friday that visits to two Syrian security centers contained proof of widespread, arbitrary detentions and torture by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Political Prisoners Freed in Myanmar
item.description: President Thein Sein pardoned at least 20 political prisoners on Friday, just ahead of a state visit to the United States, and more releases are expected.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Angry Egyptian Police Close Gaza Crossing
item.description: Egyptian police officers blocked the Rafah crossing into the Gaza Strip on Friday to protest the kidnapping of seven of their colleagues by Islamist gunmen, witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: British Poisoning Inquest Constrained
item.description: A coroner overseeing a British inquest into the poisoning of a former Russian security agent ruled that he had to exclude evidence on whether the Russian state was involved in the killing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
